clusters.title: Donald Trump Is Saying There's a TikTok Deal. China Isn't
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Says Xi Approves TikTok Deal, Plans South Korea Meeting

items.title: Donald Trump Is Saying There's a TikTok Deal. China Isn't
items.standfirst: Donald Trump claimed victory on a deal that would put TikTok in the hands of his allies after a call with Xi Jinping. But details on the agreement—and Beijing's buy-in—remain murky.
items.content: Donald Trump claimed victory on a deal that would put TikTok in the hands of his allies after a call with Xi Jinping. But details on the agreement—and Beijing's buy-in—remain murky.

items.title: Trump and Xi to meet in South Korea as US president hails TikTok deal
items.standfirst: Trump says Chinese counterpart approved sale of video app’s American operations
items.content: Trump says Chinese counterpart approved sale of video app’s American operations

items.title: Trump says he and Xi "made progress" on TikTok deal
items.standfirst: President Trump said he "made progress" on the approval of a deal to resolve ownership of TikTok during a "very productive" conversation with Chinese President Xi Jinping.
items.content: President Trump said he "made progress" on the approval of a deal to resolve ownership of TikTok during a "very productive" conversation with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

items.title: TikTok Deal Is Closer to Approval, Trump Says After Call With Xi
items.standfirst: The US and China are closer to final agreement on a sale of TikTok’s US operations to American investors, President Donald Trump said after a call with his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping that focused in part on a deal to spare the popular app from a ban.
items.content: The US and China are closer to final agreement on a sale of TikTok’s US operations to American investors, President Donald Trump said after a call with his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping that focused in part on a deal to spare the popular app from a ban.

items.title: Trump says talk with China's Xi yielded progress, including on TikTok
items.standfirst: Officials have been working on a deal to bring popular video app TikTok under U.S. ownership to avoid shutting it down in the United States.
items.content: Officials have been working on a deal to bring popular video app TikTok under U.S. ownership to avoid shutting it down in the United States.(Image credit: Michael Dwyer)

items.title: Trump says Xi approves of TikTok deal as leaders plan South Korea meeting
items.standfirst: The president hailed "progress" during a phone call with Xi and said that he also would travel to China next year.
items.content: The president hailed "progress" during a phone call with Xi and said that he also would travel to China next year.

items.title: LIVE: Trump says Xi call ‘productive’, leaders to meet in November
items.standfirst: US president says the pair will meet at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in South Korea in November.
items.content: US president says the pair will meet at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in South Korea in November.

items.title: Trump says call with China's Xi on TikTok was 'productive' and he plans to visit China next year
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump is set to speak with Chinese leader Xi Jinping on Friday as they try to finalize a deal to keep the popular short-video app TikTok operating in the United States.
items.content: President Donald Trump is set to speak with Chinese leader Xi Jinping on Friday as they try to finalize a deal to keep the popular short-video app TikTok operating in the United States.

ai_summary: Trump claimed progress on a TikTok deal after a call with Xi Jinping, but details remain unclear.
The US and China are closer to an agreement on the sale of TikTok's US operations.
Trump and Xi plan to meet at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in South Korea.
Trump said he would travel to China next year, following the "productive" call.
Officials are working on a deal to bring TikTok under US ownership to avoid a ban.

items.title: Nato intercepts Russian fighter jets on ‘reckless’ violation of Estonian airspace
items.standfirst: Italian air force heads off three MiG-31s over Gulf of Finland amid increased tension on alliance’s eastern borderNato has intercepted three Russian MiG-31 fighter jets that violated Estonia’s airspace over the Baltic Sea in a 12-minute incursion, calling it proof of Moscow’s “reckless” behaviour.The EU’s top diplomat, Kaja Kallas, a former Estonian prime minister, accused Moscow of an “extremely dangerous provocation” and said the latest Russian violation of Nato’s eastern borders “further escalates tensions in the region”. clusters.title: Senate fails to pass short-term funding bill that would avert government shutdown – US politics live
clusters.neutral_headline: Senate Fails to Pass Funding Bill, Government Shutdown Looms

items.title: Senate fails to pass short-term funding bill that would avert government shutdown – US politics live
items.standfirst: Republican-controlled Senate rejects continuing resolution that cleared the House Today, lawmakers in the House will vote on legislation, known as a “continuing resolution” (CR), to prevent a looming government shutdown at the end of September.The bill, introduced by Republicans, would fund the government until 21 November. According to Politico, House GOP whip Tom Emmer was confident, as of Thursday, that his party had enough votes. “We’re going to pass this,” he said in an interview. Continue reading...
items.content: Republican-controlled Senate rejects continuing resolution that cleared the House Today, lawmakers in the House will vote on legislation, known as a “continuing resolution” (CR), to prevent a looming government shutdown at the end of September.The bill, introduced by Republicans, would fund the government until 21 November. According to Politico, House GOP whip Tom Emmer was confident, as of Thursday, that his party had enough votes. “We’re going to pass this,” he said in an interview. Continue reading...

items.title: House-passed GOP funding bill to avoid shutdown fails in Senate
items.standfirst: A Republican measure to keep the government funded past Oct. 1 stalled in the Senate after clearing the House on Friday.
items.content: A Republican measure to keep the government funded past Oct. 1 stalled in the Senate after clearing the House on Friday.

items.title: House passes spending bill as Democrats protest healthcare cuts: ‘We don’t work for Trump’
items.standfirst: US nears government shutdown after Democrats oppose Republican bill that ‘guts healthcare’US politics live – latest updatesThe US federal government drew closer to a shutdown on Friday, after Democrats made good on their vow not to support a Republican-backed measure that would extend funding for another two months because it did not include provisions to protect healthcare programs.The GOP-controlled House of Representatives had in the morning approved a bill to extend government funding through 21 November on a near party line vote, but Democrats swiftly blocked it in the Senate, where most legislation must receive at least some bipartisan support. Republicans, in turn, rejected a Democratic proposal to extend funding through October while preventing cuts to health care programs, setting up a standoff that could see federal agencies shutter and workers sent home just nine months into Donald Trump’s term. Continue reading...
items.content: US nears government shutdown after Democrats oppose Republican bill that ‘guts healthcare’US politics live – latest updatesThe US federal government drew closer to a shutdown on Friday, after Democrats made good on their vow not to support a Republican-backed measure that would extend funding for another two months because it did not include provisions to protect healthcare programs.The GOP-controlled House of Representatives had in the morning approved a bill to extend government funding through 21 November on a near party line vote, but Democrats swiftly blocked it in the Senate, where most legislation must receive at least some bipartisan support. Republicans, in turn, rejected a Democratic proposal to extend funding through October while preventing cuts to health care programs, setting up a standoff that could see federal agencies shutter and workers sent home just nine months into Donald Trump’s term. Continue reading...

The Senate vote was 44 in favor and 48 against, short of the 60 votes…

items.title: Speaker Johnson reacts to House vote on government funding
items.standfirst: The House of Representatives has approved a short-term continuing resolution to keep the government funded for seven weeks. This comes as some questioned if Republicans had enough votes in the lower chamber to avert a government shutdown. CBS News' Nikole Killion has more.
items.content: The House of Representatives has approved a short-term continuing resolution to keep the government funded for seven weeks. This comes as some questioned if Republicans had enough votes in the lower chamber to avert a government shutdown. CBS News' Nikole Killion has more.

ai_summary: A Republican-controlled Senate rejected a short-term funding bill.

The US government drew closer to a shutdown as a result.
The bill would have extended government funding through November 21.

clusters.title: FTC sues Ticketmaster, saying it uses illegal tactics to make fans pay more for live events
clusters.neutral_headline: FTC Sues Ticketmaster, Alleging Illegal Tactics

items.title: FTC sues Ticketmaster, saying it uses illegal tactics to make fans pay more for live events
U.S. regulator sues Ticketmaster and Live Nation, alleging illegal resale tactics
items.standfirst: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general sued Ticketmaster and its parent company on Thursday, saying they are forcing consumers to pay more to see live events through a variety of illegal tactics.
items.content: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission and a bipartisan group of state attorneys general sued Ticketmaster and its parent company on Thursday, saying they are forcing consumers to pay more to see live events through a variety of illegal tactics.

items.title: Fans Paid Billions More — Now Ticketmaster Faces A Monumental FTC Lawsuit
items.standfirst: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC), joined by seven states, on Thursday filed suit against Live Nation Entertainment, Inc. (NYSE:LYV) and its subsidiary Ticketmaster, accusing the companies of facilitating illegal ticket brokering and deceiving consumers with hidden fees and resale practices. The…
items.content: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC), joined by seven states, on Thursday filed suit against Live Nation Entertainment, Inc. (NYSE:LYV) and its subsidiary Ticketmaster, accusing the companies of facilitating illegal ticket brokering and deceiving consumers with hidden fees and resale practices. The…

items.title: FTC accuses Live Nation, Ticketmaster of illegally reselling tickets
items.standfirst: Regulators allege Ticketmaster used deceptive pricing and sales tactics, costing consumers billions of dollars.
items.content: Regulators allege Ticketmaster used deceptive pricing and sales tactics, costing consumers billions of dollars.

items.title: Live Nation and Ticketmaster accused of allowing ticket brokers to rake in millions from resales
items.standfirst: FTC and seven states file lawsuit claiming resellers’ violations of ticket purchasing limits were ignoredThe US Federal Trade Commission and seven states accused Live Nation and its ticketing arm Ticketmaster of costing fans millions of dollars by tacitly allowing ticket brokers to scoop concert tickets and sell them at a significant markup, the agency said on Thursday.The lawsuit deepens Ticketmaster’s legal woes, which began after its botched 2022 sale of tickets to Swift’s much-hyped Eras tour. Continue reading...
items.content: FTC and seven states file lawsuit claiming resellers’ violations of ticket purchasing limits were ignoredThe US Federal Trade Commission and seven states accused Live Nation and its ticketing arm Ticketmaster of costing fans millions of dollars by tacitly allowing ticket brokers to scoop concert tickets and sell them at a significant markup, the agency said on Thursday.The lawsuit deepens Ticketmaster’s legal woes, which began after its botched 2022 sale of tickets to Swift’s much-hyped Eras tour. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The FTC sued Ticketmaster and Live Nation for alleged illegal tactics.
The lawsuit claims Ticketmaster uses tactics to make fans pay more.
The FTC alleges deceptive pricing and sales tactics, costing consumers billions.
Seven states joined the FTC in the lawsuit against Ticketmaster.
The lawsuit claims Ticketmaster allowed ticket brokers to profit from resales.

items.content: Authorities had been searching for Travis Decker since May 30, when he didn't return his three daughters to their mother's home in Wenatchee, Washington.

clusters.neutral_headline: White House Asks Supreme Court to Halt Passport Sex Marker Order

items.title: White House asks supreme court to halt judge’s order on passport sex markers for trans people
items.standfirst: Judge’s order order allows transgender or non-binary people to request a male, female or ‘X’ markerThe Trump administration on Friday asked the US supreme court to halt a judge’s order allowing transgender and non-binary people to choose the sex marker on their passports.The justice department filed an emergency request to lift a federal judge’s order that bars the US state department from enforcing a Trump-directed policy. Continue reading...
items.content: Judge’s order order allows transgender or non-binary people to request a male, female or ‘X’ markerThe Trump administration on Friday asked the US supreme court to halt a judge’s order allowing transgender and non-binary people to choose the sex marker on their passports.The justice department filed an emergency request to lift a federal judge’s order that bars the US state department from enforcing a Trump-directed policy. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump administration asks supreme court to allow firing of Fed’s Lisa Cook
items.standfirst: Request sets stage for historic test of presidential power as Trump pursues greater control of the Federal ReserveThe Trump administration asked the US supreme court to allow it to fire the Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, as it continues its extraordinary attack on the central bank’s independence.In a filing on Thursday, Donald Trump’s officials requested an emergency order to remove Cook from the Fed’s board of governors, after an appeals court refused to go along with efforts to oust her. Continue reading...
items.content: Request sets stage for historic test of presidential power as Trump pursues greater control of the Federal ReserveThe Trump administration asked the US supreme court to allow it to fire the Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, as it continues its extraordinary attack on the central bank’s independence.In a filing on Thursday, Donald Trump’s officials requested an emergency order to remove Cook from the Fed’s board of governors, after an appeals court refused to go along with efforts to oust her. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The White House asked the Supreme Court to halt a judge's order.
The order allows transgender and non-binary people to choose their passport sex marker.
The Justice Department filed an emergency request to lift the order.
The Trump administration also sought to fire Fed's Lisa Cook.
The request sets up a test of presidential power.

clusters.title: What to know about Erika Kirk, Charlie Kirk's widow and Turning Point USA's new CEO
clusters.neutral_headline: Erika Kirk to Lead Turning Point USA After Husband's Death

items.title: What to know about Erika Kirk, Charlie Kirk's widow and Turning Point USA's new CEO
items.standfirst: Erika Kirk, 36, has a devotional podcast and Christian clothing line. She has vowed to continue her late husband's work.
items.content: Erika Kirk, 36, has a devotional podcast and Christian clothing line. She has vowed to continue her late husband's work.(Image credit: Samuel Corum)

items.title: Erika Kirk, widow of Charlie Kirk, to helm TPUSA
items.standfirst: Kirk will take over one of the most influential conservative organizing groups from her late husband.
items.content: The board of conservative youth organization Turning Point USA voted unanimously to hand over the reins of the group to Erika Kirk, widow of political activist Charlie Kirk. In a statement, the group said Thursday that Charlie Kirk had expressed to executives that he wished for his wife to take over as chief executive and board chair in the event of his death. “We will not surrender or kneel before evil,” the group’s board members wrote. “We will carry on. The attempt to destroy Charlie’s work will become our chance to make it more powerful and enduring than ever before.” Erika Kirk, a graduate of Liberty University, won the Miss Arizona USA pageant in 2012 and went on to start her own podcast, clothing brand and nonprofit organization, and married the political organizer in 2021. Charlie Kirk cofounded TPUSA in 2012. She is set to speak at a memorial for her deceased husband at State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona — home to the Arizona Cardinals football team — alongside President Donald Trump, Vice President JD Vance and several senior administration officials. The influential political organization has seen a surge in interest from young conservatives since the fatal shooting of its leader last week at a university in Utah. In the week following Charlie Kirk’s killing, the group said it had received more than 50,000 requests from high school and college students to start a chapter with the organization’s network or join an existing one. Erika Kirk vowed to carry on her husband’s legacy in the wake of his death, committing to “make Turning Point the biggest thing this nation has ever seen” in public remarks just hours after authorities announced the arrest of Tyler Robinson, a 22-year-old Utah man now charged with aggravated murder. Republicans intend to elevate Charlie Kirk’s killing as they look to the 2026 midterm elections, highlighting what they call radical left-wing violence and aiming to carry on his legacy of mobilizing young voters to turn out for Republicans.

ai_summary: Erika Kirk, widow of Charlie Kirk, will become the new CEO of Turning Point USA.
She has a devotional podcast and a Christian clothing line, according to reports.
Kirk has vowed to continue the work of her late husband, Charlie Kirk.
Politico reported that she will take over a prominent conservative organizing group.
The organization is one of the most influential conservative groups in the United States.
